title: Clipboard : Jensen putting up strong numbers for Twins Triple A team in St . Paul
body_text:
Playing for his third organization in a year, Ryan Jensen is displaying the dominance that made him a first-round draft choice, taming opponents on the mound for the Minnesota Twins Triple-A affiliate in St. Paul.
The hard-throwing right-hander is 3-1 on the season with a 2.29 earned run average, striking out 31 hitters in 19.2 innings.
Jensen, who attended Salinas High, has made 15 appearances for St. Paul, with one start. Opponents are hitting just .200 against him.
Blessed with a fastball that approaches the century mark, Jensen was the 27th overall selection by the Cubs in 2019, losing a year in 2020 because of the pandemic.
Last year, the 26-year-old spent time with the Cubs and Mariners Triple-A affiliates, signing in the off-season with the Twins.
Jensen, who earned all-county honors in football and baseball at Salinas, has struck out 278 hitters in 235.1 innings over parts of five minor league seasons.
A second team All-America in 2019 at Fresno State, Jensen went 12-1 in his final college season with 107 strikeouts in 100 innings, earning Mountain West Pitcher of the Year honors.
Honors piling up for Amaral
A week after being named to the Atlantic Coast Conference softball first team as a freshman, Addison Amaral was chosen to the Mid-Atlantic Region second team for the University of Notre Dame.
Amaral, who set a freshman school record for the Fighting Irish with 10 home runs, led the team in homers and runs batted in (53), the most by a freshman since 2007.
The Herald’s Female Athlete of the Year last season, Amaral hit .340 for the Fighting Irish, leading the team in doubles and extra base hits, while finishing second in runs scored.
A member of The Herald’s All-County teams in volleyball and softball while at Notre Dame in Salinas, Amaral sported a .934 fielding percentage in her first season at second base.
Career season for Berring at Santa Clara
JonJon Berring has established college career highs in eight different categories this spring for the Santa Clara University baseball team.
The Palma product leads the Broncos in hitting at .327, as well as doubles (12), steals (15) and on-base percentage (.448).
Hitting near the top of the order, the 5-foot-7 Berring shattered his career total for home runs with nine in 38 games, while walking 29 times, driving in 28 runs and scoring 41.
Berring has been outstanding in the outfield as well, having handled 61 of 63 chances for a .968 fielding percentage.
A member of The Herald’s All-County football and baseball teams, Berring has improved his batting average in each of his four seasons at Santa Clara.
A teammate of Berring’s for the Broncos is former Alisal High and Hartnell College pitcher Sebastian Schreiber.
The left-handed hurler has made 18 appearances for Santa Clara, including one start, having struck out 14 in 18 innings with one save.
Riggenbach closes out career
Logan Riggenbach, who established a Portland State softball school record for consecutive games without an error, finished her career by starting all 47 games this past spring.
The 5-foot-10 former all-county outfielder from Notre Dame led the Vikings in doubles with 12, while hitting .248 with 21 runs batted in.
During her four years at Portland State, Riggenbach produced a .306 lifetime batting average, with 10 homers and 85 runs batted in, recording 140 hits.
Teammate and Salinas High graduate Natalia Martinez finished with a career-high .280 batting average in 42 starts at third base.
The junior slugger went 8-for-15 in her final four games with a homer and four RBI for Portland State, which finished the year 23-24.
Wrestling warriors
Alvarez High’s Keira Siason and Valeria Cardoso, along with Alisal’s Areli Rodriguez helped the Santa Clara Valley Wrestling Association club team to a pair of top three team finishes at the CA USA Association Duals.
The club finished second in freestyle and third in Greco. Cardoso, who announced she will wrestler next year at Menlo College, competed at 145 pounds.
Siason, a state meet qualifier last winter at 106 pounds, competed at 110, while Rodriguez, a two-time state meet qualifier for Alisal, wrestled at 170 pounds.
Synchronized sensations
Seven synchronized swimmers from the Cypress Swim Club are headed to the National Junior Olympic Championships.
The significant seven of Brielle Capiaux, Sofia Carmona Young, Daphne and Elena DeCarlo, Elyse DeSalvo and Reagan and Scarlett Dotterer were champions in two prestigious competitions.
Competing in the 16-19 age class in the free combination routine, the seven won gold medals in both the Pacific Association Invitational and the West Zone Region B championships in Walnut Creek.
The Youth age group team (under 16) of Carmona Young, Elena DeCarlo, DeSalvo and the Dotterer sisters placed sixth in the team routine. More than 200 competitors took part in the competition.
Coaches needed
Alisal is looking for a head boys and girls wrestling coach. Contact jose.gil@salinashsd.org or call 831-796-7600. Three letters of recommendation are required.
Carmel is looking for a varsity cross-country coach, a varsity girls volleyball coach, a varsity girls basketball coach and a varsity girls water polo coach. Apply at www.carmelunified.org.
North Salinas is looking for a field hockey coach, a varsity flag football coach and a varsity boys volleyball coach. Contact jeankinn.ashen@salinasuhsd.org.
Salinas is looking for a girls’ junior varsity volleyball coach. Contact Chloe Goldman at 831-776-0304.
Marina is looking for a varsity girls volleyball coach, a varsity boys volleyball coach, a varsity baseball coach and a varsity girls flag football coach. Go to www.edjoin.org/MPUSD.
Hartnell College basketball camps
Hartnell College will host a series of youth basketball camps. The Panthers’ men’s staff and players will conduct a co-ed camp for ages 5-14 from June 10-13 from 9 a.m. to noon.
The Hartnell women’s team and staff will hold a co-ed camp for ages 5-14 from June 17-20 from 9 a.m. to noon, with an elite girl’s camp slated for June 17-20 for ages 12-18 from 12:30-3:30 p.m.
For more information, contact jvenegas@hartnell.edu or call 831-755-6830.
